revised_title: Robert Hooke's Architectural and Surveying Contributions to Post-Great Fire London
tldr: The article discusses the architectural and surveying work of Robert Hooke in post-Great Fire London. Hooke, a member of the Royal Society, was appointed as one of the surveyors of the City of London and worked alongside Christopher Wren. He contributed to the rebuilding of the city, including designing and erecting various public buildings and private houses. Hooke also proposed a scheme for a new quay along the river and played a significant role in the rehabilitation of the Fleet River, which was a major challenge at the time.
